Article.ArticleTitle: Catalytic oxidation of sulfachloropyridazine by MnO<sub>2</sub>: Effects of crystalline phase and peroxide oxidants.

AbstractText: Catalytic activation of different oxidants including peroxymonosulfate (PMS), peroxydisulfate (PDS), hydrogen peroxide (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) and ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) by MnO<sub>2</sub> for degradation of sulfachloropyridazine (SCP) was investigated and the effects of different crystalline phases of MnO<sub>2</sub> including nanowire α-MnO<sub>2</sub>, nanorod β-MnO<sub>2</sub>, nanofiber γ-MnO<sub>2</sub>, and nanosphere δ-MnO<sub>2</sub> on catalytic ozonation of SCP were also studied. The SCP degradation and total organic carbon removal indicated that the oxidation efficiency of the peroxide oxidants followed an order of O<sub>3</sub>/MnO<sub>2</sub> > PMS/MnO<sub>2</sub> > PDS/MnO<sub>2</sub> > H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/MnO<sub>2</sub>. In catalytic ozonation, SCP degradation rate constants of different MnO<sub>2</sub> phases followed an order of δ-MnO<sub>2</sub> > α-MnO<sub>2</sub> > γ-MnO<sub>2</sub>> β-MnO<sub>2</sub>. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) suggested that hydroxyl radicals (·OH) and singlet oxygen (<sup>1</sup>O<sub>2</sub>) might be more significant for SCP degradation than sulfate (SO<sub>4</sub><sup>·-</sup>) and superoxide (·O<sub>2</sub><sup>-</sup>) radicals. Radical competition experiments demonstrated that <sup>1</sup>O<sub>2</sub> and ·OH contributed to 63.16% and 28.07%, respectively, for the catalytic ozonation of SCP. It was also found that more oxygen vacancies, specific surface area and exposure of MnO<sub>6</sub> edges could facilitate the activation of O<sub>3</sub> for <sup>1</sup>O<sub>2</sub> and ·OH productions and SCP degradation. The degradation pathways of SCP could mainly follow the cleavage of S-C or S-N bond and dechlorination, accompanied by hydroxylation and oxidation.
